div1.p: Sternberg states that Reed is an excellent medical officer and zealous student of medical science as well as an expert pathologist and bacteriologist. The reports are dated June 30, 1896 and July 3, 1896. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Walter Reed, June 30, 1896

(FORM A.)

Individual Service Report of Surgeon Walter Reed for
the fiscal year ended June 30, 1896.
STATION Washington, D.C.,
DATE July 3, 1896.
TO THE Surgeon General, U.S.A.
Washington

SIR: I have the honor to report that during the year my station and duties were as follows:
From July 1, 1895, to June 30, 1896,
station Washington, D.C., duties Curator, Army Med. Museum.
From, 189, to
station, duties

station, duties
1. During the year I was present for duty 346 days, and present sick ----- days,
and absent from my station or from my official duties--
(a) On detached service ----- days.
(b) By verbal permission 20 days.
(c) By authority of ordinary official leave ----- days.
* (d) Authorized delays in reporting for duty ----- days.
(e) Absent on sick leave ----- days.
2. Married or single Married. Number in family 4.
Outside the routine duties of my position, I have studied or pursued a course of reading--
3. In the line of the military profession -----
4. Professional or scientific study and investigation other than military
Investigation into the Etiology of
vaccinia.
5. Foreign languages studied Italian and German.
(a) Able to speak Italian
(b) Able to translate Italian, French & German
6. Business experience, nature and extent of None.
7. Subjects or titles of books written or published, essays prepared, lectures delivered or papers
read, when and where
(a) “Investigation of lesions in liver in typhoid fever”-Johns Hopkins Hosp.
Reports. Volume V. 1896.
(b) Course of lectures on Bacteriology & Clinical Microscopy
(c) Army Medical School.
Remarks

I certify that the entries herein made are true to the best of my knowledge and belief.
Walter Reed,
Surgeon, U.S.A.
NOTE.--Under “Remarks” give any necessary explanation of any answer for which the allotted space is insufficient.

*This will include the elapsed time from the date when an order for relief from duty at any station takes effect
to the date of reporting at a new station, less the estimated time that would have been required in transferring duties
and in the journey to the new station, had there been no delay en route for convenience of the officer.

(FORM B.)
(Commanding Officer's Report--under Pars. 807 and 811, A. R., 1895. A separate blank to be used for each officer.)

Curator, Army Medical Museum Surgeon General's Office.
3. What duties other than those of routine were performed by him? Professor of Clinical and
Sanitary microscopy and director of the pathological laboratory. Army
Medical School. Delegate to the meeting of the American Medical Association
Baltimore, Md: Member Medical Examining Board, S.O. 224, A.G.O. Sept 25, 1895.
4. Habits, general conduct and bearing Excellent
5. Professional zeal and ability Excellent
6. The condition and discipline of men under his immediate control Good
7. Capacity for command Good
8. State specifically the staff duties, or other details for which he has any peculiar fitness or

An expert pathologist
& bacteriologist.
9. Should he be intrusted with important duties requiring discretion and judgment?
Yes
10. Has he been specially mentioned, favorably or unfavorably, in official reports of command-
ing officers? If yes, give reference to reports
11. Is he qualified mentally, morally, and physically for all the duties of his position? If no,

Yes

Remarks: An excellent medical

I certify that the entries herein made are true and impartial, to the best of my knowledge and

G.M. Sternberg
Surg. Gen. U.S.A.

NOTE.--In answer to queries 4, 5, 6, and 7, degrees of efficiency will be expressed as “excellent,” “good,” “toler-
able,” or “not good.” Whenever an officer is marked “not good,” the reason for such answer must be clearly stated,
and a copy of that portion of the report will be furnished to the officer concerned, who will be granted a reasonable
time to prepare such written statement in respect thereto as he may desire to make: this statement will be indorsed
and forwarded with the report. Should the officer not desire to make a statement, that fact will be noted. If in
arrest, the cause, if known, and name of officer ordering the arrest will be stated. Under the head of “Remarks,”
any appropriate explanations may be made for which other allotted spaces are insufficient.
